response.answer_text: Nothing. Nothing can stop the growing debt problem faced by the U.S. or, for that matter, that of almost every other country in the world. Most people blame the debt problem on temporal issues like the COVID pandemic and the trillions that our politicians have shoveled out to help stem its economic effects. While that has perhaps worked, and will likely ebb post-pandemic (whenever that comes), our towering deficits will remain. Those deficits are built into our modern political system. They are a function of promises needed to propel progressive campaigns in our democracies, including promises of consumption support made decades ago, primarily for Social Security and Medicare. These two programs alone cost about three quarters of a trillion dollars per year, outspending everything else we think of as the federal government. So, tax the “rich,” right? I see a lot of that, including in the list of responses below. But even if our “rich” were forced to liquidate their holdings and hand it over to Congress, it wouldn’t be enough to pay for even several months of those programs, let alone for all the others envisioned by the far left in their unicorn plans. But those plans, and the need for their political opponents to at least somewhat keep up with those irresponsible promises, will prevent anything resembling the fiscal sanity needed to bring our deficits under control. Even they start to do so, it’s probably too late. The liabilities for our existing programs are greater than the total net worth of the United States, including every share of stock owned by every billionaire. For those of you not financially savvy enoughbto understand what that means, I will quote one of my favorite movie villains: “It means you’re broke. You just haven’t run out of cash.” And for the MMT loons who believe that the U.S. can simply print as much as it wants (or even better, just add zeroes to electronic accounts created out of thin air!), I have no answer except to say that magical thinking will not save us. The governments of our most liberal states, like California, New York, and Illinois, are all facing down the threat of bankruptcy. They are counting on the Federal government to bail them out. That’s why Nancy Pelosi is holding up massive additional aid against the effects of COVID. She wants to bail out her state. CNN and the NYT unsurprisingly seem to overlook any mention of that particular sticking point, but that’s all of the reason for the hold up. But to the extent the Democrats succeed in saving their states, and pushing for the same policies at the federal level that have gotten their states into so much trouble, they are simply hastening the day that the U.S. hits the same wall. Except no one can bail out the U.S., even if we were willing to sell our sovereignty to do so, which is what overly indebted nations have had to do in the past. And I don’t want to imply that Republicans can save us. Republicans in power have proven to be just as fiscally irresponsible, just with regards to other priorities, and at not as much of a breakneck pace (aside from the temporal problems they had to face, and with full support of the Democrats). The only consolation may be that it’s not just us. Every major country in the world has fallen into the debt trap. They have had to in order to compete. No one will be spared. Not the EU. Not Japan. Not China. “Europe makes universal health care work!” Europe is even more f*cked than our Democratic states. Your family may have that crazy uncle who spends profligately on himself and his family and friends, mindlessly blowing his credit card limits, then cashing in on his home equity to desperately make the payments. We all see the crash coming like a slow motion train wreck, and warn him of the impending doom if he doesn’t reform his spendthrift ways. And at some point, when he realizes it’s too far gone, he says, “what difference does it make at this point. Might as well enjoy myself while I can.” The day of reckoning always comes. I’m watching it now with my Uncle Sam.
